Graphical abstract In this article, a structure of heterojunction solar cell configured as Ti (front contact)/p-phosphorene/n-cSi/Ag (back contact) has been simulated by using AFOSR-HET v2.5 software. Here, electronic nature of phosphorene layer which is anisotropic along armchair and zigzag directions has been considered as 3D in nature instead of 2D. After optimizing the parameters of p-type single layer phosphorene and n-type crystalline silicon (n-cSi) maximum power conversion efficiency 15.51% and 14.06% has been achieved for armchair and zigzag phosphorene, respectively. The temperature dependence of the cell performance has been studied and maximum efficiency has been found at 300 K for both armchair and zigzag phosphorene layer. Further, we have studied the effect of metal contact on the cell performance. We have also simulated the solar cell taking experimentally available parameters of n-cSi and efficiencies of 13.29% and 14.06% are found in cases of the armchair and zigzag phosphorene layers, respectively. Finally, we have demonstrated that multilayer p-type phosphorene layer could act as an effective transparent conducting electrode in the silicon heterojunction solar cell. Keywords Phosphorene Silicon heterojunction solar cell AFORS-HET software Transparent conducting electrode 1 Introduction Recently, as a physical analogue to the graphene, single atomic thick layer of black phosphorus (BP) known as phosphorene has emerged as a promising material for next-generation transistor applications due to its superior carrier transport properties. Previously, BP’s instability in the air was considered as a major challenge for its potential application in the devices that operate in an ambient environment [1]. Recently, air stability of BP layers has been improved by depositing an Al2O3 layer on the surface [1,2]. In further advances, it is reported that BP possesses a direct band gap of 0.3–2.0 eV depending on the layer number and mobility as high as 10,000 cm2/V s compared to 200–517 cm2/V s in other 2D materials [3–5]. Recently Ge et al. [6] reported that as-synthesized BP is p-type with carrier density 4.2 × 1018/cm3, equivalent to 2 × 1011/cm2 for each layer of BP. Du et al. [7] reported that chemical doping with 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane (F4-TCNQ) makes the few-layer black phosphorous (FLBP) to p-type. Also, He et al. [8] theoretically predicted that F4-TCNQ enhances the p-type conductivity in single layer phosphorene due to strong charge transfer between its molecule and layer. Furthermore, the sheet resistance of mechanically exfoliated layer has been reported to be in the range of 100–1000 kΩ/sq and after doping with F4-TCNQ this reduces to 2.5 times [1,7]. Optical absorbance was reported to be 2.8% and 5.5% in single and bilayer phosphorene, respectively confirms its high transparency [9]. The work function of BP decreased rapidly from 5.16 eV to 4.5 eV as layer number increased from 1 to 5 [10]. Similarly the dielectric constant also increased rapidly from 2.9 (bilayer) to 3.5 (trilayer) [11]. Above discussed properties of FLBP motivates us to use the p-type FLBP in silicon-based heterojunction solar cell as a transparent conducting electrode. Generally, a transparent conducting electrode in the heterojunction solar cell allows the light to pass through the interface and also introduces a built-in potential at phosphorene/Si interface to separate the photogenerated carriers. Recently, application of phosphorene in various areas such as transistors, memory devices, and batteries has been demonstrated [2]. However, the utilization of phosphorene in a solar cell has not been explored much and few reports on the application of phosphorene in solar cell application are available. In 2016, theoretically, Hu et al. [12] proposed that edge-modified phosphorene nanoflakes can act as donor and acceptor materials in heterojunction solar cell and efficiency of 20% has been predicted. Experimentally, liquid phase exfoliated black phosphorous has been used in the organic solar cell. Lin et al. [13] have used the thin layer of phosphorene as anode buffer layer in device structure configured as Glass/ITO/PEDOT:PSS/BP/PTB7:PC71BM/Ca/Al. After inserting phosphorene layer, a reduction in efficiency from 7.72% to 6.52% was reported. Thus, optimization of layers’ parameters of phosphorene as well as silicon is required to obtain a cost-effective high-efficiency solar cell. Hence in this report, the cell structure of p-phosphorene/n-cSi under air mass 1.5 (AM1.5) illumination with a power density of 100 W/cm2 using AFORS-HET (Automat FOR Simulation of HETero-structures) software was simulated. This software solves the 1D semiconductor equations-Poisson’s equation and the transport equation for electrons and holes with the help of finite difference under different conditions, i.e. steady state condition, equilibrium condition, etc. In the proposed simulation, we have taken the p-phosphorene as a conducting electrode and n-cSi as an absorber layer. Furthermore, we have considered p-phosphorene 3D in electronic nature instead of 2D. The parameters of both p-phosphorene and n-cSi layers are optimized to obtain the highest efficiency for p-phosphorene/n-cSi solar cell. The simulation was also performed considering the anisotropic nature of phosphorene layer. The objective of the simulation is to study the independent effects of anisotropic behavior of phosphorene as well as Si layer on the performance of the cell and understand the insight behind cell response. 2 Simulation structure As shown in Fig. 1 (a), the structure of heterojunction solar cell configured as Al2O3/Ti/p-phosphorene/n-cSi/Ag has been simulated. In order to prevent the degradation of phosphorene layer in air, capping layer of Al2O3 is employed [1,2] and to minimize the reflection from the layer, its thickness was kept 40 nm [14]. Here Ti [2,15–17] and Ag are used as front and back contacts, respectively. The Fermi wavelength of the 2D system is given by the relation λ F = 2 π n 2 D , where n2D is the carrier density in cm−2 [21]. Recently, Saito et al. have reported the sheet carrier density in BP up to 3 × 1013 cm−2 [22]. So, if n2D approaches ∼3 × 1013 cm−2, then λF is found to be 4.576 nm. Hence, doped six layer phosphorene (∼3.96 nm) will satisfy the condition 〈t〉 ≤λF, where 〈t〉 is the average thickness for 2D electron system. Therefore, the facts discussed above motivated us to consider multilayer phosphorene as quasi 3D in nature. Here, the quantum confinement was achieved by reducing the thickness. At the interface, electrons are diffused from n-cSi to p-phosphorene and holes from p-phosphorene to n-cSi until thermal equilibrium gets established. As p-phosphorene/n-cSi junction is illuminated, electron-hole pairs (EHP) are generated and then separated due to built-in potential. These free minority carriers move towards the p-phosphorene and n-cSi, respectively, as shown in Fig. 1(b). Due to the accumulation of these carriers, Fermi level shifts upward in n-cSi and downward in p-phosphorene, respectively and as a consequence VOC develops. It has been reported earlier that the value of VOC become independent of wafer thickness (Wb) if Li ≪ Wb [46,47]. The maximum value η = 15.51% was achieved at 100 μm of the n-cSi wafer. After optimizing Si parameters the structure was again simulated by varying the layer number of phosphorene from single layer to 20 layers. The results are shown in Fig. 3(i and j), η was found to decrease from 15.51% to 13.21% as layer number increased from 1 to 20. To have better practical realization, we have further simulated considering the parameters of commercially available Si. We have taken the value of ND = 1015cm−3, NC = 2.8 × 1019 cm−3, NV = 1.04 × 1019 cm−3 χ = 4.05 eV, μn = 1500 cm2/Vs and μp = 450 cm2/Vs for n-cSi as reported in Refs. [37,48]. We have varied the thickness of Si wafer from 10 µm to 300 µm. The maximum value of η is found 9.83% for 100 µm thick commercial available n-cSi wafer. In order to study the effect of metal contact, we have simulated our device taking the front contact of Au metal [16,17]. The thickness of Au contact was kept 70 nm and the n and k values are taken as (1.2152, 1.8434) and (0.155, 3.6024) at 480 nm and 650 nm wavelength, respectively [19,49]. In both wavelengths, the efficiencies were found to be 0.1281%. When the thickness of Au contact was reduced to 2 nm, η reached up to ∼ 8% for both wavelengths. This increase in η confirms that 2 nm Au contacts absorb less photon and allow the photons transmission through it to reach the junction. But the decrease in η from 15.51% (Ti contact) to 0.1218% and ∼8% (Au contact) might be due to absorption of more photons by Au contact than Ti contact and prevents the photons to pass through it to reach the junction. The further simulation was done by changing the front contact to scandium (n = 1.1198, k = 1.1548 at ∼190 nm wavelength [49]. First, the thickness of this contact was considered 2 nm and achieved ∼11% efficiency. As this thickness was increased to 10 nm the η was found to decrease up to 0.7633%. We have also optimized the cell parameters considering zigzag phosphorene layer and maximum efficiency of 14.06% was achieved (see Supplementary Figs. S2 and S3). 4 Spectral response, quantum efficiency and temperature dependence In a solar cell, spectral response (SR) is the ratio of current generated by the solar cell to the optical incident power on the cell and quantum efficiency measures the effects of optical losses such as transmission, reflection etc. through the cell. In order to investigate the spectral response (SR) and quantum efficiencies, simulation was carried out at illumination condition of the monochromatic intensity of 1 × 1016 cm2 s−1 and 10 nm spectral widths in the range of 300–1200 nm as mentioned in software. The spectral response (SR), internal quantum efficiency (IQE) and external quantum efficiency (EQE) of the best optimized simulated solar cell (η = 15.51%) are shown in the Fig. 4 (a–c). As shown in Fig. 4(a) SR was found to increase from 0.206 to 0.362 A/W as wavelength increased from 300 to 600 nm. Above 600 nm SR decreased and dropped to 0 A/W at 1200 nm. As revealed from magnified Fig. 4(e), photons are absorbed more in 300–600 nm wavelength region which increased JSC in accordance with equation SR = J SC ( λ ) I light ( λ ) , here JSC (λ) is short circuit current density; Ilight (λ) is intensity of the incident light [50]. In a solar cell, IQE refers to efficiency of photons neither reflected nor transmitted out of the cell, whereas EQE includes the effect of optical losses such as reflection and transmission from the cell. In Fig. 4(b and c) IQE and EQE of the best-optimized cell were found to be 0.852 and 0.851 at 300 nm wavelength. The maximum values of IQE and EQE were found to be 0.915 and 0.914, respectively at 400 nm. Above 400 nm both IEQ and EQE were found to be decreased and reached to 0 at 1200 nm. The IQE is defined as IQE ( λ ) = 1 1 - R ( λ ) hc e λ SR , [50] which can also be written as IQE ( λ ) = 1 A ( λ ) + T ( λ ) hc e λ SR , where R (λ) is the reflectivity, h = plank’s constant, c = velocity of light, e = electric charge λ = wavelength of incident light (nm) and following the relation used in the software R (λ) + A (λ) + T(λ) = 1, A(λ) = absorptivity and T(λ) = Transmittance. Following IQE vs A(λ), T (λ) and SR, the increase of IQE within the range of 300–400 nm is directly proportional to the SR. But above 400 nm the absorption of photons by the phosphorene layer might be increased and resulted in a decrease of IEQ. Similarly, EQE can be defined as EQE = J ( λ ) qF 0 ( λ ) [ 1 - R ( λ ) ] = J ( λ ) qF 0 ( λ ) [ A ( λ ) + T ( λ ) ] , here J (λ) is total current density, F0(λ) is the incident photon density per wavelength interval, q is the total electric charge(q = ne) [51]. From this equation, it can be estimated that in the wavelength range of 300–400 nm, phosphorene layer might absorb less number of photons and allow them to transmit through it to reach the Si layer, which results in an increase of J as well as EQE. After above 400 nm, the phosphorene layer might absorb a large number of photons and prevents them to reach Si layer. As a result, J (λ) as well as EQE decrease. SR, IEQ, and EQE of best optimized zigzag phosphorene/n-cSi (η = 14.06%) solar cell are shown in supplementary Fig. S4(A). In order to study, the temperature dependence of cell response simulation of the best-optimized cell (η = 15.51%) was carried out in the temperature range from 300 to 400 K, and the results have been shown in Fig. 5 (a and b). VOC was found to decrease from 655.5 mV to 493 mV whereas JSC was found to increase slightly from 28.66 mA/cm2 to 29.37 mA/cm2 as temperature increases. Since band gap, energy and temperature are related to E g ( T ) = E g ( 0 ) - α T 2 α + β , here Eg (T) is the band gap of the semiconductor at any temperature T, Eg (0) is the band gap energy at T = 0 Kelvin, α and β are the material constant [41]. According to E-T relation as mentioned above, as temperature increases band gap decreases. It is also reported that Jo increased as temperature increased [41] and resulted in decrease of VOC. In addition, at lower Eg large numbers of absorbed photons have enough energy to create e-h pairs and JSC gets increased. The FF and η are found to decrease due to decrease of VOC. The maximum efficiency η = 15.51% is found at temperature 300 K. Optimized cell parameters have been summarized in Table 3 . The variation of parameters with temperature of the best optimized zigzag phosphorene and n-cSi is shown in supplementary Fig. S4(B). 5 Conclusions In order to develop a cost-effective heterojunction Si solar cell, the structure Ti/p-phosphorene/n-cSi/Ag has been proposed and simulated using AFROS-HET-v2.5 software to optimize the layer's parameters. Effect of eight parameters of phosphorene was analyzed individually. After optimizing parameters of phosphorene (arm-chair) and n-cSi wafer maximum efficiency η = 15.51% was achieved whereas η = 14.06% in case of zigzag. Our simulation reveals that the efficiency does not depend much on anisotropic nature of phosphorene. Simulated results demonstrate that if the stability of phosphorene in the air can be controlled then it can act as an efficient transparent electrode in the silicon heterojunction solar cell. coredata.dc:description: In this article, a structure of heterojunction solar cell configured as Ti (front contact)/p-phosphorene/n-cSi/Ag (back contact) has been simulated by using AFOSR-HET v2.5 software. Here, electronic nature of phosphorene layer which is anisotropic along armchair and zigzag directions has been considered as 3D in nature instead of 2D. After optimizing the parameters of p-type single layer phosphorene and n-type crystalline silicon (n-cSi) maximum power conversion efficiency 15.51% and 14.06% has been achieved for armchair and zigzag phosphorene, respectively. The temperature dependence of the cell performance has been studied and maximum efficiency has been found at 300 K for both armchair and zigzag phosphorene layer. Further, we have studied the effect of metal contact on the cell performance. We have also simulated the solar cell taking experimentally available parameters of n-cSi and efficiencies of 13.29% and 14.06% are found in cases of the armchair and zigzag phosphorene layers, respectively. Finally, we have demonstrated that multilayer p-type phosphorene layer could act as an effective transparent conducting electrode in the silicon heterojunction solar cell.
